channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Questions About Tactics and Targets as Civilian Toll Climbs in Israeli Strikes
item.description: A strike that killed 25 members of four households gathered for Ramadan was the latest in a series of Israeli attacks that have hit families in their homes.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian children were among those attending the funeral on Monday of people who were killed in their home by an Israeli airstrike in Khan Younis, Gaza.

item.title: Britain Announces Inquiry Into Killing of Ex-K.G.B. Officer
item.description: The decision to look into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko could be taken by Russia as a further rebuke as it faces Western opprobrium over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Twitter Acts Quickly on Suspect Pro-China Accounts
item.description: Just hours after The New York Times posted an article about bogus Twitter accounts dedicated to spreading pro-China propaganda, Twitter appears to have hit the kill switch on a score of the suspect accounts.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: A screen grab of a since-suspended Twitter account that Free Tibet identified as fake.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Now Prefer Mobile When Going Online
item.description: The results of a new survey showed that more Chinese are heading online to send instant messages (through popular mobile apps like Tencent’s Weixin, or WeChat), listen to music, play video games and read.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: A group of young Chinese checking their mobile phones on a park bench in Beijing.

item.title: Europeans Debate Tougher Sanctions on Russia
item.description: Foreign ministers of the 28-nation European Union were likely to endorse a schedule of measures but delay imposing them.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Israel Confirms One Soldier Is Missing in Gaza
item.description: Until now, the military had said it was “looking into” Hamas’s assertion that it had abducted a soldier, saying it was unable to confirm or deny the claim.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Bodies of Crash Victims Safely Moved Out of Combat Area
item.description: The train was met by forensic experts and other representatives of countries that had citizens on the jet downed last week in territory controlled by pro-Russian rebels.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: A train carrying remains of passengers from Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 arrived Tuesday in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills Guards at Police Compound Near Kabul Airport
item.description: At least four security guards were killed Tuesday after the bomber reached an area occupied by trainers from DynCorp International, an American military contractor.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Turkey’s Culture Wars
item.description: The battle between religious conservatives and secularists is fought most fiercely over women’s bodies.
item.dc:creator: By ELIF SHAFAK

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Flight Delays Expected to Worsen in Eastern China
item.description: Many airports in China already have terrible records for on-time departures — and it’s about to get worse.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Passengers waiting to board their plane at Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Will Iraqi Blacks Win Justice?
item.description: Iraqis need to recognize that theirs is a multiethnic country, and that respect for minority rights is what makes any nation strong.
item.dc:creator: By SAAD SALLOUM

item.title: Russia’s Message on Jet: Conciliation and Bluster
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin seems to be probing for a way out of the crisis of the downed Malaysia Airlines jet without appearing to compromise with the West.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin visited an aerospace center in Samara, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Journalist Fired Over Work for Hong Kong Website
item.description: Song Zhibiao was forced to terminate his contract on Friday with China Fortune, a monthly magazine owned by Southern Metropolis Daily, after he wrote commentaries for a Hong Kong-based website.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Campaign Tries Tapping Into Hong Kong’s ‘Silent Majority’
item.description: A campaign aiming to deter a mass protest by those who favor a more direct election of Hong Kong’s top leader collected 380,000 signatures in its first two days.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: A volunteer put a signed form into a ballot box during the anti-Occupy Central campaign organized by the Alliance for Peace and Democracy in Hong Kong.

item.title: Businessman Wanted in Fatal South Korean Ferry Disaster Is Found Dead
item.description: Yoo Byung-eun was a church leader and businessman whom prosecutors had hoped to arrest in connection with the ferry disaster that killed more than 300 people.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Strength Is Sought at Rites in Israel
item.description: The discovery of Hamas’s tunnel network and the continual rocket fire from Gaza have kept support for the conflict high among Israelis, who say they would encourage a cease-fire if the threats are eliminated.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Loved ones in Holon, Israel mourned the death of Maj. Tzafrir Baror.

item.title: World Briefing: Kuwait: Citizenship Is Revoked for Five
item.description: Kuwait’s cabinet stripped five people of their citizenship on Monday, meaning they lose their rights to government jobs, benefits and voting.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Study Tracks Millions of Child Brides
item.description: More than 700 million women alive today were married as children, and more than one in three were wed before they reached 15, Unicef said in a study.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Rhinos May Be Split Up
item.description: A wildlife reserve is weighing a plan to move some rhinos out, aiming to protect them from poachers by spreading the risk to other game reserves.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Deadly Clash at Syrian Border
item.description: A Turkish soldier was killed and two others were injured late Monday in Ceylanpinar, a town in Sanliurfa Province on the Syrian border.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: To Talk With Hamas, U.S. Needs Help From a Testy Trio of Nations
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry will be leaning heavily on Egypt, Turkey and Qatar — which have deep divisions over the Islamic movement — to help broker a cease-fire as quickly as possible.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Arriving in Cairo on Monday, Secretary of State John Kerry was greeted by Nabil Habashi, Egypt’s minister of foreign affairs protocol chief, ahead of a diplomatic push to forge a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas fighting.

item.title: Jet Wreckage Bears Signs of Impact by Supersonic Missile, Analysis Shows
item.description: A piece from the Malaysia Airlines plane in Ukraine, examined in photographs by defense consultants, had damage consistent with that from a fragmenting warhead, the kind carried by an SA-11 missile.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: A piece of wreckage from the Malaysia Airlines jet downed over eastern Ukraine last week shows damage, including shrapnel holes and blistered paint, that is consistent with a hit from a fragmenting warhead, according to consultants with IHS-Jane’s.

item.title: The Big Fix: Corralling Carbon Before It Belches From Stack
item.description: Many scientists say capturing the carbon that spews from power plants and locking it away is necessary to stave off the worst effects of climate change.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN
item.media:credit: Aaron Phillips for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crane work on the carbon capture section of a power plant in Kemper County, Miss.

item.title: Journey Home Finally Begins for the Victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight
item.description: The train bearing the bodies of the victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 finally began its long journey to get them out of Ukraine’s war-torn badlands and closer to home.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two Dutch forensic investigators at the train of refrigerated cars with the bodies of those killed on Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, before the train left Torez, Ukraine.

item.title: Israel Is Facing Difficult Choice in Gaza Conflict
item.description: With the lopsided casualty count mounting, world leaders are demanding a halt to the hostilities. But Israel’s ground invasion operation has uncovered more militants’ tunnels than it expected.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The mother of an Israeli soldier, Tsafrir Bar-Or, mourned during his funeral near Tel Aviv on Monday.
